Headlines ( Leaderboard Top ), pagematch: 1, sectionmatch: 1 Deployment of e-jeeps on roads pushed By Paolo Romero (The Philippine Star) | Updated February 6, 2017 - 12:00am 
MANILA, Philippines - A major transport group is pushing for the deployment this year of environment-friendly public utility jeepneys that will not only reduce pollutants and oil imports by millions of liters annually, but also increase income of operators and drivers. 
Vigor Mendoza, chairman of Kilusan sa Pagbabago ng Industriya ng Transportasyon (KAPIT), is pushing for BEEPS, or bio-ethanol powered jeepneys. 
He said BEEPS would be a practical alternative since prices of diesel and gasoline continue to rise faster as fossil fuels are expected to eventually run out. 
“We are also now in the cross roads of modernization. Whatever technology we choose should be good for the next 10 to 15 years as we cannot expect our jeepney operators to re-fleet earlier,” Mendoza said. 
There are about 200,000 registered PUJs in the country. 
“When supply becomes scarce, the price will hit the roof. We cannot be complacent as this scenario is just a matter of time,” he said. Headlines ( Article MRec ), pagematch: 1, sectionmatch: 1 
Mendoza said whatever decision the government, transport groups and other stakeholders will make on the BEEPs, it will have an impact on the country’s environment in the future. 
“Though we cannot totally leave fossil fuel-based engines yet, KAPIT believes that, as we modernize, we have to consider the impact of the technology we choose on our health and environment,” he said. 
From just P20 per liter, in less than a year diesel price jumped by 60 percent or P32 per liter. And with excise tax being eyed, diesel will hit P38 to 39 per liter, Mendoza pointed out. 
He described ethanol as a viable option as it comes from plants like sugar, corn and cassava, and is therefore renewable and promotes zero pollution. 
The use of bio-ethanol will also support the country’s energy security program as it become less dependent on imported fuels, he said. 
With ethanol, operators can shift to air-conditioned vehicles, which electric vehicles at the moment cannot do efficiently, Mendoza said. 
With the use of ethanol-powered aircon vehicles, fare pricing is 20 percent higher as compared to non-aircon jeepneys, which means added income of around P1,000 to P1,200 per day. 
He said the increased income is more than enough to offset the higher cost of ethanol fuel, which is estimated at P53 per liter. 
At this price, the average jeepney fuel cost will increase by P560 per day. But due to the increased income, there will still be a net gain of P440 to P640 per day. Headlines ( Article MRec ), pagematch: 1, sectionmatch: 1
